title.value: Canada’s provincial COVID-19 pandemic modelling efforts: A review of mathematical models and their impacts on the responses
title.justification: The title explicitly states the focus of the paper, which is on reviewing the mathematical models used during the COVID-19 pandemic and their impact on responses in Canada.
title.quote: Canada’s provincial COVID-19 pandemic modelling efforts: A review of mathematical models and their impacts on the responses

extractions.description: The paper reviews the mathematical modelling efforts for COVID-19 across Canadian provinces and their impact on public health responses. It discusses the variability in models, the data used, and the collaboration structures to address the pandemic.

type.justification: The paper includes a review and analysis of provincial COVID-19 modelling efforts by reviewing the models and the collaborations between modellers and decision-makers, which is empirical by nature.
type.quote: This study aims to describe, summarize, and analyze provincial COVID-19 modelling efforts in Canada.

name.justification: The paper addresses the use of mathematical modelling in the context of public health to guide pandemic responses.
name.quote: Setting Mathematical modelling played an important role in the public health response to COVID-19 in Canada.

name.justification: The paper explains the use of mathematical models in managing COVID-19 across provinces.
name.quote: Mathematical models of infectious diseases can integrate knowledge about the pathogen, human behaviours, and interventions to generate projections.

name.justification: The paper involves the study of epidemic trajectories and healthcare demands related to COVID-19.
name.quote: ...initial modelling efforts focused on projecting epidemic trajectories and healthcare demands.

name.justification: The paper mentions agent-based modelling explicitly as one of the models used.
name.quote: The remaining one third were agent-based or hybrid (e.g., agent-based and discrete event simulation) models.

is_contributed.justification: Agent-based models are referenced as part of existing modelling strategies rather than being newly contributed.
is_contributed.quote: Teams were identified through memberships in modelling networks and referrals.

is_executed.justification: The paper states that agent-based models were actually used in the evaluations during the pandemic.
is_executed.quote: The remaining one third were agent-based or hybrid (e.g., agent-based and discrete event simulation) models.

is_compared.justification: The paper compares various modelling strategies, including agent-based models.
is_compared.quote: Developing mathematical models for pandemic response involves trade-offs between data availability, model complexity, and computing efficiency.

referenced_paper_title.value: Estimation of COVID-19-induced depletion of hospital resources in Ontario, Canada
referenced_paper_title.justification: This is one of the referenced works in the paper that discusses modelling strategies, including agent-based models.
referenced_paper_title.quote: Barrett, K., Khan, Y. A., Mac, S., Ximenes, R., Naimark, D. M. J., & Sander, B. (2020). Estimation of COVID-19-induced depletion of hospital resources in Ontario, Canada.

name.justification: Compartmental models are explicitly mentioned as a common type used in the pandemic response.
name.quote: Two thirds of those models were compartmental (13/20) and only two of those (2/13) were stochastic.

is_contributed.justification: These models have been used in various studies prior to this review.
is_contributed.quote: Teams were identified through memberships in modelling networks and referrals.

is_executed.justification: Compartmental models were actively used in the analysis and modelling efforts described.
is_executed.quote: Two thirds of those models were compartmental (13/20) and only two of those (2/13) were stochastic.

is_compared.justification: The paper reviews different types of models, including compartmental ones.
is_compared.quote: Developing mathematical models for pandemic response involves trade-offs between data availability, model complexity, and computing efficiency.

name.justification: The paper mentions that some models used were stochastic instead of deterministic, which plays a role in pandemic response.
name.quote: Two thirds of those models were compartmental (13/20) and only two of those (2/13) were stochastic.

is_contributed.justification: Stochastic models have been a part of the traditional modelling approaches and are not newly introduced here.
is_contributed.quote: Two thirds of those models were compartmental (13/20) and only two of those (2/13) were stochastic.

is_executed.justification: Stochastic models are detailed as part of the modelling efforts utilized during the pandemic.
is_executed.quote: Two thirds of those models were compartmental (13/20) and only two of those (2/13) were stochastic.

is_compared.justification: The stochastic models are part of the overall comparison of used models.
is_compared.quote: Developing mathematical models for pandemic response involves trade-offs between data availability, model complexity, and computing efficiency.

referenced_paper_title.value: Estimation of COVID-19-induced depletion of hospital resources in Ontario, Canada
referenced_paper_title.justification: This reference in the paper discusses different modelling approaches that include discrete event simulations.
referenced_paper_title.quote: Barrett, K., Khan, Y. A., Mac, S., Ximenes, R., Naimark, D. M. J., & Sander, B. (2020). Estimation of COVID-19-induced depletion of hospital resources in Ontario, Canada.

name.justification: The paper mentions surveillance datasets as the main data sources for model calibration.
name.quote: Surveillance datasets for cases, hospitalizations and deaths, and serological studies were the main data sources for model calibration.

referenced_paper_title.value: Role of case importation in explaining differences in early SARS-CoV-2 transmission dynamics in Canada—A mathematical modeling study of surveillance data
referenced_paper_title.justification: The reference discusses the use of surveillance data in modelling SARS-CoV-2 transmission.
referenced_paper_title.quote: Godin, A., Xia, Y., Buckeridge, D. L., Mishra, S., Douwes-Schultz, D., Shen, Y., Lavigne, M., Drolet, M., Schmidt, A. M., Brisson, M., & Maheu-Giroux, M. (2021). The role of case importation in explaining differences in early SARS-CoV-2 transmission dynamics in Canada—A mathematical modeling study of surveillance data.

name.justification: The paper notes the use of serological studies to complement surveillance data for model calibration.
name.quote: ...and serological studies were the main data sources for model calibration.

referenced_paper_title.justification: The reference provides data that supports the seroprevalence discussion in the context of COVID-19 responses.
